elements.2211.03078_fe6dd51e4f64b2b50cf20a275191b: With the recent developments in cross-lingual Text-to-Speech (TTS) systems, L2 (second-language, or foreign) accent problems arise
elements.2211.03078_4a36e118645ba16fab1c69eec8a4e: Moreover, running a subjective evaluation for such cross-lingual TTS systems is troublesome
elements.2211.03078_3a6fa5fa62234a4e04518c4f56916: The vowel space analysis, which is often utilized to explore various aspects of language including L2 accents, is a great alternative analysis tool.
elements.2211.03078_1cdc3e6ba0caf2e3c24f2e0b89859: In this study, we apply the vowel space analysis method to explore L2 accents of cross-lingual TTS systems
elements.2211.03078_11a16bed9bf5a0f229249eb641fb8: Through the vowel space analysis, we observe the three followings: a) a parallel architecture (Glow-TTS) is less L2-accented than an auto-regressive one (Tacotron); b) L2 accents are more dominant in non-shared vowels in a language pair; and c) L2 accents of cross-lingual TTS systems share some phenomena with those of human L2 learners
elements.2211.03078_c9c05cec607db786fd129c2006cfa: Our findings imply that it is necessary for TTS systems to handle each language pair differently, depending on their linguistic characteristics such as non-shared vowels
elements.2211.03078_74b7764a66f6f6c46714e2e770809: They also hint that we can further incorporate linguistics knowledge in developing cross-lingual TTS systems.
elements.2211.03078_8422fa5a8d20717d0f6d13a5bb76c: Vowel space, Speech synthesis, Text-to-speech, Cross-lingual, L2 accent
elements.2211.03078_3bb45136561ce8d4ced88d925a144: Over the recent years, various approaches have been proposed to build cross-lingual Text-to-Speech (TTS) systems
elements.2211.03078_fef2a92dd33192958318ffc455f06: However, L2 (second-language) accents frequently appear in such cross-lingual scenarios, and several attempts have been made to improve its nativeness
elements.2211.03078_a76ac89a6d3b1e8ed876fcbbdd77d: To make matters even worse, subjective evaluation of less major languages is challenging, especially for researchers in a less diverse environment
elements.2211.03078_dba9d725ee0cad384b72cd9fbf07c: Running a subjective evaluation test every time can be a hassle, unless you are a fluent polygot.
elements.2211.03078_5e90faa379157312d3d7087ee0c73: The vowel space analysis method can be a nice alternative
elements.2211.03078_e23348bafd75f49d1b5fc3419ba7b: The vowel space refers to the two-dimensional area depicting the jaw opening and the tongue positions of vowels
elements.2211.03078_ebc7b5c96c4003a80813e7eb9198f: It is accompanied by the formant analysis, since the jaw opening and the horizontal position of the tongue are highly related to the first and second formant frequencies (
elements.2211.03078_fe7846ccde6156f6ef0ef3abd43ca: It is utilized to explore various aspects of language, including L2 accents
elements.2211.03078_c59e0cec4211e194c49f367f1e8f4: propose to utilize the vowel space analysis as an intermediary evaluation tool to assess accents or dialects of English.
elements.2211.03078_9e1646cec22f1f194bd160ffb749f: In this paper, we extend their vowel space analysis approach
elements.2211.03078_f5f7ed454229147b1ff4d0723ff04: We propose a cross-lingual vowel space analysis method and probe L2 accents in cross-lingual TTS systems
elements.2211.03078_7b6e87a88290a19568c463ce2bd09: To our best knowledge, this is the first attempt to utilize the vowel space analysis to investigate the L2 accents of cross-lingual TTS systems.
elements.2211.03078_9ada8e1fa411f5dab879761666ad9: In this work, we focus on the following research questions, by utilizing the vowel space analysis in cross-lingual scenarios:
elements.2211.03078_26fdaa22688b855a864b452ac1981: Do L2 accents of cross-lingual TTS systems differ by model architectures?
elements.2211.03078_5041d46850abcf93276f36a4b0ac5: How are L2 accents of cross-lingual TTS systems different by linguistic characteristics among languages?
elements.2211.03078_9fa2b7655c149d8e271b197e902fd: Is any of L2 accent observations in cross-lingual TTS systems also present in linguistics literature conducted on actual human L2 learners?
elements.2211.03078_0d4c038dec4d6d9d21984b7d0086c: To answer the questions above, we choose to explore cross-lingual TTS systems based on Tacotron
elements.2211.03078_da6377f592aac5cca10c439cc4d8d: as representative backbone models of auto-regressive and parallel (non auto-regressive) architectures, respectively
elements.2211.03078_99c3129ef4790aea089b1c9fb8501: We assess the following two factors that are commonly explored in the vowel space analysis
elements.2211.03078_78dace44643c018876201d154bfb5: : the accuracy and compactness of vowel categories
elements.2211.03078_4b4137527cee67e0e80fa7900f5c7: It has been reported that these two factors are highly correlated with L2 accents
elements.2211.03078_a97ceb90a8e8eb7b098dd4f053d9e: The vowel accuracy is the correctness of the position of a synthesized vowel, compared to its native one on the vowel space.
elements.2211.03078_ee82c7074f01556abf67bf43d7eac: The vowel compactness, or the vowel variability, is one way to assess acoustic stability among realizations of each vowel
elements.2211.03078_f78941bbb79cd4eb4ea913f1ae740: Evaluating these metrics, we compare the shared and non-shared vowels in a language pair
elements.2211.03078_532e11d75a47fcb62f584bdfe5c94: The shared vowels refer to the vowels that exist in both languages of a language pair, while the non-shared vowels do not
elements.2211.03078_8a2c6236f8c1f53c4d03938a1cf39: We inspect some of the vulnerable cases in cross-lingual synthesis, regarding these linguistic characteristics.
elements.2211.03078_92f09bbfe8722d376d3b1efc0b918: In addition, we investigate some of the L2 accent characteristics from TTS systems, that are also present in experimental results conducted on actual human L2 learners.
elements.2211.03078_6173ef0fbe3e067e0d964404ffa7d: We utilize part of the CSS10 datasets
elements.2211.03078_293c2090779796219c0916046f328: along with the LJ Speech dataset
elements.2211.03078_73a710aaa94a17a2c1d155e8e3893: and our in-house datasets recorded by professional voice actors
elements.2211.03078_8c1af9f2a1cbd7556e7c86ab4215a: The total database consists of three American English (EN) speakers, two Korean (KO) speakers, and one speaker from each of the following languages: German (DE), Spanish (ES), French (FR), and Japanese (JA)
elements.2211.03078_37c638433033a4bcc7702bd7613f0: We randomly select 300 utterances from each speaker as the test set.
elements.2211.03078_c23f141c63f6fc0c74ec5a91f9cf6: We investigate two mainstream architectures of TTS systems: auto-regressive and parallel (non auto-regressive)
elements.2211.03078_951d26699cded7ef01db991bf9a7f: as the representative model for the former, and Glow-TTS
elements.2211.03078_833f5469af479cfa380ee29df8a33: They are suitable for cross-lingual analysis, as no external forced-alignment is required.
elements.2211.03078_4f85216d2f143f012e29b1c9b786d: The Tacotron variant is a slightly modified version, utilizing the same acoustic features as the LPCNet
elements.2211.03078_c74fa360f317408acab7588b02b6d: Glow-TTS is also slightly adjusted to take the same acoustic features as input
elements.2211.03078_04c77af31ba1bea39c106305b70e6: In this paper, for simplicity, we refer this Tacotron variant and the modified Glow-TTS as Tacotron and Glow-TTS, respectively.
elements.2211.03078_4097b86050a16fc630ee1fc3a104f: as a neural vocoder to transform acoustic features into actual waveforms
elements.2211.03078_69928d63beae10196864a4367c49b: We train these systems in single speaker and multi-lingual versions.
elements.2211.03078_95dcf8a7beebc1172195a1a301f44: In the single speaker version, we use the base architecture from each model
elements.2211.03078_28ce200b1bab25830864d880f1996: , without any speaker or language embedding, only one speaker's data being separately trained
elements.2211.03078_f8ea9c7af783eb87903ec261f56ee: This single speaker version is essentially mono-lingual, therefore we assume that no L2 accent is present in this condition
elements.2211.03078_1c8b99989f57272496073fa9807cb: Hence, we set this single speaker version as the non L2-accented anchor.
elements.2211.03078_ea29f26c7405652873053ad985161: The multi-lingual version is an extended version of the single speaker version
elements.2211.03078_01e7076a07abd4dee1a4bf9baf27e: In the multi-lingual version, we utilize the speaker embedding and the language embedding from a look-up table
elements.2211.03078_354ac93829ac58ed797f3c1ffc14c: In the case of Tacotron, the speaker and language embeddings are fed to the decoder as in the
elements.2211.03078_9709bcdca838c3a09929ef85fa303: In Glow-TTS, the speaker embedding is applied as in the original architecture
elements.2211.03078_36716b55c53309f98504b823d54db: , and the language embedding is concatenated to the speaker embedding.
elements.2211.03078_1e3556736aef614779ba6ac2606b3: We train the Tacotron single speaker version for 350k steps, and the multi-lingual version for 500k steps
elements.2211.03078_ef79dc7cf6c88f48103d60590b8a4: Glow-TTS versions usually require more training steps, so we train the Glow-TTS single speaker version for 500k steps, and the multi-lingual version for 1000k steps.
elements.2211.03078_d92ad972ac3ddb1203d620d77a1b2: Other training configurations are identical to the original architectures
elements.2211.03078_6115d294da3c8e1900c560a6e33cb: We utilize the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)
elements.2211.03078_17369eaf596cc359a9bc22b048e28: as phoneme input to the TTS systems.
elements.2211.03078_0c9035ad6bfe3dace8ce4fc14feba: In the multi-lingual versions, we add a language tagging to each phoneme to differentiate the same IPA phoneme in different languages, as one IPA phoneme's actual acoustic realization as a phone may differ in each language
elements.2211.03078_c58f4eeb24c2a8064140d6f5eb1ec: For instance, the phoneme input /i/ in English and the same phoneme input /i/ in Korean are considered different input tokens
elements.2211.03078_4bcdf6cdabab469b0d5c7728bc50e: We limit our inspection scope to monophthongs, since analyzing diphthong requires a time-dynamic analysis.

elements.2211.03078_ccd00995f6cad26cd06dc8251b1c9: We extend the previous vowel space analysis approach
elements.2211.03078_5e43090cdbc2c06d4dd8e78d4476f: Our vowel analysis method comprises the following steps
elements.2211.03078_2a9bb1142a9d81371fe6863737a62: First, we extract the first and second formants of synthesized vowels
elements.2211.03078_b4c0436fd9748ddd7420c259a7ea3: Next, we apply speaker normalization to the formant values
elements.2211.03078_00d6f47a9b1a23a5ec3f130b5f4bc: Lastly, we measure vowel accuracy and compactness for analysis.
elements.2211.03078_a9f458f15b1145f7bc6b18fd68ae5: We first begin with extracting formant values
elements.2211.03078_b3205b6cc88f85c9a9a72e78ada8f: To synthesize vowels from the TTS systems, we give text input as a sequence of tokens, beginning with a target vowel followed by a silence token and a subsequent random sentence starting with a voiceless plosive consonant such as /p/, /t/, or /k/
elements.2211.03078_db08d722d8ed2448c0d9c9b92906a: Afterwards, we slice the synthesized speech by the first silence boundary and take the first segment
elements.2211.03078_fedf19fa5cfd1c3e57c20784db112: We set the threshold energy as 10 dB
elements.2211.03078_51383a7859d6a6420eec70d165e92: We empirically observed that appending a sentence beginning with a voiceless plosive consonant induces a clearer silence boundary, easing the automatic slicing process
elements.2211.03078_f1f60b7b3daf965fe07fc57952f24: values are extracted at the middle point of the chosen segment.
elements.2211.03078_e4c1784dc771d7df3e71a060efb32: We synthesize 100 samples per vowel, and set the median as the representative.
elements.2211.03078_6cc1ec30f55de67ecfdde84907421: Our approach has some advantages over the previous method
elements.2211.03078_0d0ccfb4eb3d467e03c2012da0633: First, it requires no external aligner or segmentation, thus it is free from any potential errors caused by an external segmentation tool
elements.2211.03078_57629e68d2c4154cd9bf449a8ff5d: It can also be utilized to low resource languages where no aligner or segmentation tool is publicly available
elements.2211.03078_99b3e959a1e9eeca12d787e021e29: Second, it minimizes the co-articulation effect by nearby phonemes in the cross-lingual scenarios
elements.2211.03078_5934f78aea2a6435c07ac71438323: For example, the conventional hVd test
elements.2211.03078_367b45d5aa8f46e737dd29846aebf: does not apply equally to some languages such as French and Japanese, where syllable-initial /h/ and syllable-final /d/ are not allowed, respectively
elements.2211.03078_8df06e62dc4df194be685f79d978d: Third, it is closer to the actual usage scenario of TTS systems than the previous method
elements.2211.03078_6eca8ea76d4595e94674aac2a8802: , multiple hVd words with an in-between pause are given as text input
elements.2211.03078_fd819fa4d91978baf0436ac319b22: However, this is slightly astray from what a TTS system usually is trained for
elements.2211.03078_469398eef0cae8ffeebec76c6fb20: Compared to this, our method is more coherent with the real world usage of TTS systems.
elements.2211.03078_42d02ce260d12fb576ab17e949183: values in the vowel space vary by speaker
elements.2211.03078_ec4cf63b46bf3ec98ca4bea379866: In order to extend Abeysinghe et al.'s approach
elements.2211.03078_c294cd75aead4bce1f0f6202c7ca7: to cross-lingual TTS systems, a speaker normalization process should precede
elements.2211.03078_36860c193b319f43db619170578be: We apply the renowned Lobanov normalization method
elements.2211.03078_12ff0774a0917dace8c3b57a58028: to normalize speaker information on the vowel space, as many other linguistics researchers have proven its effectiveness
elements.2211.03078_fbdfea320e125f83c0741e136b6f0: After the speaker normalization process, we visualize the vowels on the vowel space diagram, where the normalized
elements.2211.03078_b9471c2715b0c03d378f11031d46f: values are depicted in the reversed
elements.2211.03078_c15a6578737d3080b05383686a153: shows the vowel space of a male Korean speaker after the formant estimation and speaker normalization process
elements.2211.03078_7999885ba63d4a74f22393e34f34a: The positions of the vowels in the vowel space correspond to those from Korean phonology
elements.2211.03078_060fb8059c1641ba8524877399d88: We focus on the following two factors that are commonly investigated in the cross-lingual analysis: accuracy and compactness of vowel categories
elements.2211.03078_d37b17f5e5adf3831cfa9ac11d7b2: It has been frequently reported that L2 accent perception is highly correlated with these two factors
elements.2211.03078_249d457adabba21726b21a8ed45a5: The vowel accuracy, or correctness, is the distance to the native productions of the target vowels
elements.2211.03078_5d5e766a6311611bc0914feb75571: Assuming that non cross-lingual TTS systems are not L2-accented, we measure the vowel accuracy by calculating the Euclidean distance between the non-accented target vowel and the corresponding vowel which is cross-lingually synthesized
elements.2211.03078_149a0f8f4685444a8641cfd60e38f: The greater vowel distance indicates the more L2-accented speech
elements.2211.03078_bc83e75189b289b599c6ecf6ba616: The vowel compactness, or variability, is one way to evaluate acoustic stability among vowel productions
elements.2211.03078_a5eaedcd8196ce86414076758c7c8: It is measured by calculating the standard deviation of each vowel
elements.2211.03078_3a7ffe85c1b53570ef83641622e7f: The greater vowel standard deviation, or less compactness, implies the more L2-accented speech.
elements.2211.03078_f7373e3f5f5911c052cde7d198336: We first examine if L2 accents differ by the model architecture
elements.2211.03078_7b61573cf137bf65cb0dcc5b345c7: shows the mean vowel distance and the standard deviation of cross-lingually synthesized vowels from Tacotron and Glow-TTS
elements.2211.03078_29746a5f29201c11da1b0f3f6680b: Glow-TTS exhibits lower values in both metrics than Tacotron
elements.2211.03078_246a4449448f043622938a6a70b24: This implies that the L2 accent is more severe in Tacotron compared to Glow-TTS
elements.2211.03078_a904af2196235dd3be76d4f4cfb54: This phenomenon may arise from their different nature in auto-regressiveness, that is, auto-regressive systems are more influenced by preceding input tokens than its parallel counterpart during training
elements.2211.03078_518757bbdc8173cb3156521beb55e: However, further investigations are required to more clearly understand why Tacotron performs more poorly than Glow-TTS in cross-lingual speech synthesis.

elements.2211.03078_0b75e4ab4ebae4c2c224033171a26: We also explore if L2 accents of cross-lingual TTS systems are influenced by the linguistic characteristics among languages and if any of the observations appears in linguistics literature on actual human L2 learners
elements.2211.03078_39908dc7308e5d0ad71901ef4c320: We begin by comparing shared and non-shared vowels in a language pair
elements.2211.03078_c30a7e320457c089953f74f35c4bf: The shared vowels are the vowels that appear in both languages in a language pair
elements.2211.03078_314aaa23d663cc3b813707b92f658: For example, /i/ and /u/ are examples of the shared vowels in the English-German pair
elements.2211.03078_6844cbb0c72a7452b5231ada720e4: On the contrary, the non-shared vowels appear only in one language in a language pair, such as the German umlaut /
elements.2211.03078_981afaffbfdd316215e09ae951e18: , the vowels that are not shared in a language pair exhibit lower vowel accuracy and compactness, which indicate that the non-shared vowels are more prone to L2 accents
elements.2211.03078_44eef9e05c2a5589d1707c7cd61e7: The fact that unseen sounds are usually harder to process is one possible explanation for this result
elements.2211.03078_7ee4c7a06b9f5b596a2a48bacaf62: Considering that the shared vowels in different languages are regarded as different text input tokens, the chance is low that this result is caused by sharing the same text input tokens.
elements.2211.03078_6e2cad4e2b1c493c1fa407badbb5b: A phenomenon similar to this is also observed in some studies on human L2 learners, that adult L2 learners exhibit difficulty with non-native phonological segments
elements.2211.03078_0500afa2b452d94fb97e913a15790: The vowel accuracy is the lowest when the target language is German regardless of the source language, as shown in Figure
elements.2211.03078_025b54e286b67fed4c1c0f1341a39: It is also low when the source language is either Spanish or Japanese, especially in Tacotron
elements.2211.03078_a75808e43c6095859192d8061afbb: This result may be related to the number of vowels each language has
elements.2211.03078_c56e871efb882bfaef5c72b6f64d4: The German language has approximately 17 vowels (monophthongs), while Spanish or Japanese has only five
elements.2211.03078_87642c5b7de4552eb49fa2a2ab475: When German is the target language, more unseen vowel sound categories should be created from the source language, and this is the most prominent in the languages with five vowels.
elements.2211.03078_6eafeb6809d77649a4ba3f7230059: Similarly, human L2 learners experience more difficulty when the number of new sound categories they need to learn increases
elements.2211.03078_3611442abbab67fb42673efca9de4: Poor performance is observed when the target language is Japanese in Glow-TTS as in Figure
elements.2211.03078_82b783d99b438849eb3086061959f: This may arise from lack of explicit pitch accent information, which such parallel-based systems often require to properly model the Japanese language
elements.2211.03078_ac253ba678fca12e95bfcaf53cac2: We inspect some vowels that are especially prone to L2 accents
elements.2211.03078_70d22bff40e27e47b8ed5bdf1be6b: To list a few, the French nasal vowels and the Korean vowel /
elements.2211.03078_379d7a112cd30520eee8a840f055c: / rank top, probably because these vowels exist uniquely in each language
elements.2211.03078_6ce6ec08a916dca231c731aedbf1b: / on the vowel space along with other cross-lingually synthesized /
elements.2211.03078_3ac3c0f9a5e57f99d2f463fc660e9: All of the cross-lingually synthesized samples are located in the upper region compared to the native one, which means too much jaw closing
elements.2211.03078_a17e1758dd7b7860248454a5bacc9: / when the source language is Japanese seems to be the least distant
elements.2211.03078_819be0559fb9ee83c974312fe56e5: One possible reason is that the Japanese /u/ is usually realized as [
elements.2211.03078_bfae6a8ab52a7cce085150832dcfb: ] (close back compressed vowel), slightly closer to the Korean /
elements.2211.03078_d976eeaa17dfb9f566334d716c13e: Hence, when the source language is Japanese, the Korean /
elements.2211.03078_f6c3ddf86cf82d92dfab123ff1d26: / is relatively less unseen compared to other European languages
elements.2211.03078_acfea0d10e38dcbd517fb7a112ea7: / tend to be more distant from that of Korean, when the source language is one of the three European languages (German, English, and Spanish), as they have distinct vowel systems from Korean
elements.2211.03078_4dbf586936397369f9c484848a289: In addition, some linguistics study suggests that Korean-English bilingual children speakers often assimilate the Korean /
elements.2211.03078_b3845133e51e8b833ad5b4911c7bf: , and this phenomenon partly corresponds to our findings, as the jaw opening value (
elements.2211.03078_0eca44752ec75033cce7e79ea650e: Our findings suggest that it may be necessary to consider linguistic characteristics among languages to mitigate the L2 accent issue
elements.2211.03078_bc60e5eb88a31e662894f576c5886: For instance, an additional module, embedding, or loss function properly reflecting these linguistic characteristics in a language pair may help improve any L2 accents in cross-lingual scenarios
elements.2211.03078_88247e05e2d766147e0425bd3fff2: These observations also imply we can utilize linguistics studies conducted on humans to develop TTS systems
elements.2211.03078_cef37243a394610bfaad18019f373: Our work may even be utilized as auxiliary information for building a new database or balancing an existing one.
elements.2211.03078_4516e4229f8f0c25a98d993265738: In this study, extending the vowel space analysis method to cross-lingual TTS systems, we explore L2 accents in such TTS systems
elements.2211.03078_73b7aac5110134aae8c1a46e8421c: We also compare some of observations on cross-lingual TTS systems with linguistics studies conducted on humans
elements.2211.03078_0f9ba55c8fe080b13de12d74abf30: We hope our interdisciplinary study on cross-lingual TTS systems provides inspiration in relevant fields
elements.2211.03078_244642d5344c8d0fe91821142bc5b: Based on what we have discovered, we are planning to mitigate the L2 accent problem in such cross-lingual TTS models, by proposing additional loss functions based on the linguistic characteristics in a language pair.
